item.title: In Turkey, Mourning the Dissident Khashoggi While Cracking Down on Dissent
item.media:description: Dissidents, journalists and activists in a courtyard of the Fatih Mosque in Istanbul on Friday to honor Jamal Khashoggi.
item.description: Arab dissidents, journalists and activists honored Jamal Khashoggi in one of Istanbul’s holiest mosques on Friday. But across the city, the police made a new round of arrests.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: C.I.A. Concludes That Saudi Crown Prince Ordered Khashoggi Killed
item.media:description: The Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, in March in Washington.
item.description: Intelligence officials briefed lawmakers on Capitol Hill this week and offered the agency’s analysis of the assassination and Prince Mohammed’s culpability.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES

item.title: As Brexit Options Dwindle, New Momentum for a 2nd Referendum
item.media:description: Stickers and placards left at the British cabinet office during a march last month in London calling for a People’s Vote on the final Brexit deal. Hundreds of thousands of people attended the march.
item.description: Theresa May’s plan for Britain to leave the European Union looks unlikely to get through Parliament, leaving few options. That makes a second referendum a real prospect.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Theresa May and Her Brexit Deal Are on the Brink. Here’s What We Know.
item.media:description: Competing Brexit demonstrations on Thursday outside Parliament.
item.description: Ministers resign, the pound wobbles, the prime minister makes a pitch to the public: Here’s where we are amid the rolling chaos over a draft Brexit deal.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: British Austerity Is ‘Inflicting Unnecessary Misery,’ U.N. Poverty Expert Says
item.media:description: Professor Philip Alston, the United Nations special rapporteur for extreme poverty and human rights, meeting with food bank users in Newcastle, England, last week.
item.media:credit: José Sarmento Matos for The New York Times
item.description: Conservative policies are directly linked to a rise in poverty, and the country’s leadership is in “a state of denial.”
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: How the Trump Administration Stepped Up Pursuit of WikiLeaks’s Assange
item.media:description: National security officials have long viewed Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, with hostility and considered him a threat.
item.description: As American spies worked to collect intelligence on Julian Assange, Justice Department prosecutors took steps that resulted in secret charges.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES, ADAM GOLDMAN and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Scandals Catch Up to Private Chinese Hospitals, After Fortunes Are Made
item.media:description: Mansions built with wealth from the Putian network of private hospitals, behind a pair of farmers in the village of Dongzhuang in southern China.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The Putian network of 8,000 facilities, which expanded rapidly with little government oversight, is facing national outrage and scrutiny over a death and fraud allegations.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE
item.category: National Health and Family Planning Commission (China)

item.title: Argentine Submarine That Vanished With 44 Aboard Is Found, Navy Says
item.media:description: A commemoration Thursday in Mar del Plata, Argentina, for the crew of the San Juan, a year after the submarine disappeared. The Argentine Navy said Saturday that the vessel had been found.
item.description: The San Juan, which disappeared a year ago, was found almost 2,600 feet below the ocean’s surface by a private company the government had hired, the navy said.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: The Saturday Profile: From Encyclopedic Collector to ‘Wikipedian-at-Large’
item.media:description: Mike Dickison, New Zealand’s first Wikipedian-at-Large, in the library of the Auckland War Memorial Museum. “If I find something I’m passionate about, I need to share it and get other people involved too,” he said.
item.media:credit: Cornell Tukiri for The New York Times
item.description: Mike Dickison was a museum curator when he turned to another form of curating, teaching fellow New Zealanders how to beef up their country’s presence on the website.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Khmer Rouge’s Slaughter in Cambodia Is Ruled a Genocide
item.media:description: Photographs of victims of the Khmer Rouge at the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Four decades after the Communist movement’s reign of terror, two surviving senior leaders are held accountable in a genocide verdict that opens the door for other rulings.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Chinese City Bans Daytime Dog Walking in a Crackdown on Canines
item.description: New rules in Hangzhou also banned large breeds and led to the confiscation of unlicensed dogs.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY

item.title: The Newest Weapon in Sri Lankan Politics: Chile Powder in the Eyes
item.description: For several weeks, the island nation has been paralyzed by a three-way duel involving its top leaders. Friday was yet another day of chaos in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Deport American Who Tried to Enter From China
item.media:description: The heavily militarized border between the Koreas. The American who tried to cross into North Korea from China last month had tried to enter the country from the South last November, and was detained by South Korean soldiers.
item.description: In an apparent gesture of good will, the North said it would release the man, who it said entered the country illegally a month ago.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: American Missing in Mexico Was Killed by Drug Cartel Member, Officials Say
item.description: Family and friends were baffled by the disappearance of Patrick Braxton-Andrew of North Carolina. Mexican officials now describe “a cowardly and brutal murder, of a totally innocent person.”
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: ‘Tell Everyone We Scalped You!’ How Caste Still Rules in India
item.media:description: Geetabai Jatav with her husband, Sardar Singh Jatav, center, at the government hospital in Gwalior. Mr. Singh, a dalit, was attacked by higher-caste men.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.description: While India is undergoing tremendous change, caste discrimination is still a force. Those who rebel against are often met with unchecked brutality.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: The Kilogram is Dead. Long Live the Kilogram!
item.media:description: A one-kilogram sphere of single-crystal silicon, one of the roundest man-made objects in the world. The object helped redefine a kilogram in terms of the number of atoms it contains.
item.media:credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times
item.description: After a vote (and a century of research), the standard measure for mass is redefined, and the long reign of Le Grand K is ended.
item.dc:creator: XIAOZHI LIM
item.category: International Bureau of Weights and Measures
National Institute of Standards and Technology

item.title: Canada Letter: Justin Trudeau’s Official Fixer-Upper
item.media:description: The security cameras are on, but no one’s ever home at the prime minister’s official residence in Ottawa.
item.description: The official home of Canada’s prime minister is in such disrepair that Justin Trudeau wouldn’t live there. But no politician seems willing to do anything about it.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Assange, Wildfires, Disney: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Families Sue Jordan Over 2016 Deaths of 3 U.S. Green Berets
item.media:description: A funeral service for Staff Sgt. Kevin J. McEnroe, who was killed in Jordan, at Arlington National Cemetery in 2016.
item.description: The soldiers’ fathers accused the kingdom of falsely telling the news media that the Green Berets had provoked the deadly shooting by a base guard.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)

item.title: The Shortlist: What Is America’s Role in the World? Three Authors Offer Very Different Views
item.description: In new books, Jeffrey Sachs looks beyond exceptionalism, Michael Beckley describes unrivaled power and Robert Kagan favors pragmatic leadership.
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY KARABELL
item.category: The Jungle Grows Back: America and Our Imperiled World (Book)

item.title: Greek Leader’s Efforts to Loosen Church-State Ties Are Met With Skepticism
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, right, and the head of the Greek Orthodox Church, Archbishop Ieronymos, announcing a tentative deal this month to remove clerics from civil service payrolls and to resolve a longstanding dispute over church property.
item.media:credit: Andrea Bonetti/Greek Prime Minister's Office, via Associated Press
item.description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras wants to remove clerics from Greece’s civil service, raising concerns about job security and even national identity.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: If Gaza Brings Down Netanyahu’s Government, Can He Rise Again?
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, shown at center last month in Jerusalem, is facing a call for early elections.
item.description: Already facing possible bribery charges, Israel’s prime minister, a political survivor, is grappling with political fallout over his handling of Gaza.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Global Health: Rapid Cure Approved for Sleeping Sickness, a Horrific Illness
item.media:description: Health workers, part of a mobile unit screening villagers for sleeping sickness in Yalikombo, along the Congo River in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The area is a breeding ground for tsetse flies, which spread the disease.
item.description: Parasites transmitted by tsetse flies travel to the brain, causing paranoia, fury and death. Until now, killing them required hospitalization and harsh drugs.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: ‘We Only Killed the Bad People’: 2 Khmer Rouge Leaders, Forever Linked
item.media:description: The former Khmer Rouge leaders Khieu Samphan, left, and Nuon Chea at a hearing in Phnom Penh, Cambodia’s capital, in 2013. “Let bygones be bygones,” Mr. Khieu Samphan once said.
item.media:credit: Mark Peters/Extraordinary Chambers in The Courts of Cambodia, via Associated Press
item.description: Khieu Samphan, 87, and Nuon Chea, 92, who were convicted of genocide on Friday, once hoped that the world would “let bygones be bygones.”
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Facing Tensions Close to Home, Japan’s Abe Cements Alliance with Australia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, left, and Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia lay wreaths at a memorial in Darwin on Friday.
item.description: Japan’s prime minister paid homage to Australians killed by Japanese bombs, courting the country amid wariness over China and strained ties with South Korea.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH and JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Killing Khashoggi: How a Brutal Saudi Hit Job Unfolded
item.description: An autopsy expert. A lookalike. A black van. Our video investigation follows the movements of the 15-man Saudi hit team that killed and dismembered the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

item.title: North Korea Says It Has Tested ‘Ultramodern Tactical Weapon’
item.media:description: The North’s official Korean Central News Agency released a photo on Friday that it said showed Kim Jong-un, center, supervising the test.
item.description: North Korea did not identify what weapon was tested, but the development could complicate already stalled talks between the United States and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: 8 U.N. Peacekeepers Killed in Congo in Area Facing Ebola Outbreak
item.media:description: A United Nations peacekeeper from Tanzania on patrol this week in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.description: Twelve Congolese soldiers were also killed in a joint military operation against rebels in Congo’s northeast, which is facing a deadly Ebola outbreak, according to the Security Council.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At Brexit Crunch Time, Theresa May Takes a Pummeling
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain delivering a statement outside 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.
item.description: The prime minister, who took office with the sole aim of negotiating her country’s withdrawal from the European Union, may not stay in power long enough to finish the job.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Dozens From Migrant Caravan Line Up at Border, Seeking Asylum Interviews
item.media:description: A woman receiving jackets being donated to migrants from the back of a truck on Thursday in Tijuana, Mexico, near the border fence with the United States.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The first members of the migrant caravan have begun seeking asylum interviews. Several thousand are expected by the end of the weekend.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Lawyer in Rape Trial Links Thong With Consent, and Ireland Erupts
item.media:description: Ruth Coppinger, a deputy in Ireland's Parliament, at a protest against victim blaming in Dublin.
item.media:credit: Niall Carson/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.description: On Wednesday, hundreds of people in cities around Ireland protested victim blaming in the justice system’s handling of a sexual-assault case.
item.dc:creator: VALERIYA SAFRONOVA

item.title: California Wildfires, Brexit, Yellowstone: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Letter 81: Giving Thanks, ‘Ausmerican’ Style
item.description: From small towns and juicy mangoes to the rich sounds of Sydney, the Australia bureau has a lot to be thankful for this year.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Brexit for the Non-Brit: What Is It, and Why Can’t They Get It Done?
item.media:description: Competing Brexit demonstrations on Thursday outside Parliament.
item.description: The debate has been going on for years — really, since Britain joined the forerunner of the European Union in 1973. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Former Macedonian Leader Seeks Asylum in Hungary to Avoid Prison
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban, left, in Budapest in 2015 with Nikola Gruevski, the former prime minister of Macedonia who is now seeking asylum in Hungary.
item.description: The flight of Nikola Gruevski stoked outrage and threw up another challenge to the European Union.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: Nov. 9-15
item.media:description: The bodies of 20 commandos were lined up outside the governor’s office in Sang-e-Masha, Afghanistan, on Sunday. Their company was almost entirely destroyed fighting the Taliban.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: At least 242 security force members were killed during the past week, the latest of more than 28,000 to die in the past four years.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: European Court Vindicates Aleksei Navalny, Russian Opposition Leader
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny addressing the news media in Strasbourg, France, on Thursday after Europe’s top human rights court ordered the Russian government to pay him 63,678 euros, or $72,000.
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled Russia acted with political motivations in arresting Aleksei A. Navalny, a foe of President Vladimir V. Putin
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Full Video: Theresa May Speaks on Brexit
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain spoke as her government faces a political crisis over an agreement on a plan to withdraw from the European Union.

item.title: Britons on Twitter: #BrexitShambles, #BrexitChaos
item.media:description: A demonstrator against Brexit outside the Houses of Parliament in London on Thursday.
item.description: After a dramatic morning for the British government, people in the U.K. took to social media to express their concern about Brexit.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ and ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Fists. A Flying Garbage Can. And Maybe, at Last, Negotiations in Sri Lanka
item.media:description: Rival Sri Lankan lawmakers exchanging blows in Parliament in Colombo on Thursday.
item.description: A brawl in Parliament erupts and now the divided government is talking about how to break the political deadlock that has gripped this nation for weeks.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: U.S. Levels Sanctions on 17 Saudis for Alleged Involvement in Khashoggi Killing
item.media:description: The sanctions against those accused in the killing of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi did little to quell passions on Capitol Hill.
item.description: A senior administration official said the United States was unlikely to take further steps against Saudi leaders, suggesting that both sides hope to put the episode behind them.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Afghan Military Deaths Since 2015: More Than 28,000
item.media:description: The bodies of commandos were lined up outside the governor’s office in Sang-e-Masha, Afghanistan, on Sunday. Their company was almost entirely destroyed fighting the Taliban.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: The Afghan president confirmed a much higher death rate for his security forces than previously admitted, but said the Taliban were not winning.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: With Small Steps, Palestinians and Israelis Try to Tackle Gaza’s Ills
item.media:description: A pool of sewage on a beach in the northern Gaza Strip. Treating sewage has become a problem in impoverished Gaza.
item.description: The resumption of cease-fire talks after days of violence revived hopes for joint projects on solar energy, sewage treatment and drinking water.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Saudis Shift Account of Khashoggi Killing Again, as 5 Agents Face Death Penalty
item.media:description: A billboard in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, depicting Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, left, and King Salman. The Saudis reiterated on Thursday that the team that killed Mr. Khashoggi had acted without the consent of the kingdom’s top leadership.
item.description: The kingdom’s prosecutor acknowledged that Saudi agents dismembered the dissident, but said the killing was not premeditated. Five agents face the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: At War: Are Killer Robots the Future of War? Parsing the Facts on Autonomous Weapons
item.media:description: Milrem Robotic’s Tracked Hybrid Modular Infantry System at the Changi exhibition centre in Singapore in February 2016.
item.description: Under what circumstances should militaries delegate the decision to take a human life to machines? It’s a moral leap that the international community is grappling with.
item.dc:creator: KELSEY D. ATHERTON
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brexit Deal in Crisis After 2 U.K. Cabinet Ministers Quit
item.media:description: An investment manager watching Mrs. May speak to the House of Commons. The pound dropped as much as 1.5 percent against the dollar on Thursday.
item.description: The resignations, which came the morning after Prime Minister Theresa May appeared to have gained cabinet approval for a withdrawal plan, cast doubt on her leadership.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trump to Raise North Korea Sanctions With Chinese Leader, Pence Says
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence at the Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit meeting in Singapore on Thursday.
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence said that sanctions would continue against North Korea despite concerns that China is easing enforcement.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
